possibly because it involves burning of material
Methane mitigation options for coal, oil, and gas
from coal, oil, and gas currently represent
cycle methane emissions in the coal sector occur during
underground mining, oil and gas emissions are spread throughout upstream, midstream, and
. For this reason, methane reductions from coal
mining can be accomplished through coal mine methane recovery (where methane and coal are
recovered simultaneously) and from the ventilation air, which can reduce methane emissions by 50
. Governments incentivize such operations through a
number of emissions trading and offset programs
Methane emissions in the oil and
gas sector can be reduced by leak detection and repair, relevant across varying time scales (hours to
decades) and regional scopes (component/facility level to continental)
of the methane emitted from oil and gas infrastructure can be mitigated at net
the market price of the recovered methane is higher than the mitigation costs
emissions are reduced and fossil fuel consumption decreases, methane emissions associated with these
are anticipated to decline (section 6.7). That said, substantial ‘legacy’ methane emissions
will remain even if a complete fossil fuel phase
These legacy emissions are estimated to be less than 1
80% of methane emissions from coal, oil and gas could be avoided with currently available technologies
Isaksson et al. 2020; Harmsen et al. 2019)
from abandoned coal mines could of
and gas wells, low plugging costs could be offset through methane recovery, while high plugging costs
would likely require some market or policy support
Fossil fuels could play a role in climate change mitigation if strategically deployed with CCS
. On the one hand, the primary mechanism for
reducing emissions is to eliminate the
unabated fossil fuel use. On the other hand, fossil energy combined with CCS provides a means of
carbon energy while still utilizing the available base of fossil energy worldwide and
sets. While Section 6.4.2.5 discusses the important aspects of CCS with fossil fuels,
this section aims to elucidate the feasibility criteria around these fuels itself.
Fossil fuel reserves have continued to rise because of advanced exploration and utiliza
). A fraction of these available reserves can be used consistent with mitigation goals
when paired with CCS opportunities in close geographical proximity (
continued exploration, the fossil fuel res
ource base has increased significantly; for example, a 9%
increase in gas reserves and 12% in oil reserves was observed in the U.S. between 2017 and 2018. This
increase is a result of advanced exploration techniques, which are often subsidized
. Fossil reserves are distributed unevenly throughout the globe. Coal
emaining resource (close to 500 ZJ). Conventional oil and gas resources are an
20 ZJ each). Technological advances have increased the reserves of
unconventional fossil in the last decade. Discovered ultimate recoverable resou
oil and gas are comparable to conventional oil and gas
